articles.title: People deriving income solely from state pension won’t be taxed, says chancellor
articles.trailText: Clarification creates prospect of two-tier system for retirees solely on new state pension and those on private schemes
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves has pledged that retirees whose sole income is the basic or new state pension will not face income tax on their payments, even when the new pension rises above the £12,570 personal allowance in 2027-28. Although the weekly rate will reach £241.30 (£12,547/year) in April 2026, threshold freezes would push it above the allowance by 2027, triggering small tax bills. The measure aims to reduce administration for those without private or additional state pensions but raises fairness concerns, with 2.5m on the old pension already taxed and private savers unprotected. No costings are yet provided.

articles.title: Freeze on student loan repayment threshold could leave graduates struggling, NUS warns
articles.trailText: Graduates in relatively low-paid jobs earning close to minimum wage will have to repay ‘more, much sooner’
articles.summary: The National Union of Students (NUS) warns that freezing the plan 2 student loan repayment threshold at £29,385 from April 2027 for three years will force graduates earning close to the national living wage to start 9% deductions on precarious incomes, exacerbating struggles with rent, bills and food. Currently set at £28,470, the threshold freeze affects those who began courses in England and Wales between 2012 and 2023. The Treasury defends the move as fair to non‐graduates, while the OBR forecasts it will raise about £400 million annually.

articles.title: Coupling up: how to avoid money worries in your relationship
articles.trailText: From joint bank accounts and pooled savings to mortgages and tax allowances, talk about money for a happy financial future together
articles.summary: Couples should start early, open money talks and draw up a written plan to agree budgets, debt and savings, then review it after life changes. Decide whether to pool income in a joint current account or keep solo accounts alongside a joint one for shared bills, splitting contributions equally or by income. Explore joint savings for shared goals (up to £170k FSCS protection, rising to £240k), boost mortgage borrowing jointly, add partners to cheaper car and life cover, claim the marriage allowance and maximise inheritance tax relief.

articles.title: Reeves’s plan to cut cash Isa limit could raise mortgage rates, say finance bosses
articles.trailText: Building societies fear consumers will be put off from saving if chancellor’s budget announces a 40% reduction
articles.summary: Finance bosses warn Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s planned cut of the cash ISA limit from £20,000 to £12,000 will reduce deposits funding mortgages, push rates higher and deter savers. Building Societies Association and Nationwide say fewer tax-efficient funds could curb first-time buyer lending and complicate ISA transfers. Brokers at Lodestone forecast tighter lending; FT-linked £4,000 cap rumors were scaled back. Investors may instead flock to premium bonds, say experts. Reeves will expand the Help to Save scheme to 1.5m low-income savers, making it permanent amid record £103bn cash ISA subscriptions in 2023-24.

articles.title: Small print on signs at a tram park and ride hid the fact I could get clamped
articles.trailText: I followed the obvious signs but an enforcement officer had to point out a notice on the back of the entrance sign and it cost me £140
articles.summary: At Nottingham’s NET Forest Tram Park & Ride, reader RB parked after walking in the adjacent park and used the tram, but her car was still clamped because she hadn’t bought a tram ticket on arrival—a requirement printed in tiny green text on the back of site signs. After paying a £140 release fee and losing an appeal citing unclear signage, she learned that Nottingham city council’s bylaws permit clamp enforcement on its PFI-run sites, overriding 2012 rules against private-land clamping and DfT guidance limiting clamps to repeat offenders. Tramlink’s CEO maintains the “clearly visible” signage and fee are justified.

articles.title: Ryanair expects me to take the financial hit for helping others
articles.trailText: As a doctor I stepped in to tend to an elderly passenger … but it won’t waive £100 transfer fee to rebook
articles.summary: A doctor flying from London Stansted to Pescara stopped to treat an elderly passenger who fell on an escalator, causing a 15-minute delay and missing her flight. Ryanair refused to waive the £100 rebooking fee, leaving her to pay £211 for a Rome flight, £127 for a hotel stay and drive 150 miles to Pescara. The airline insisted that passengers must present at the gate 30 minutes before departure and declined any goodwill gesture despite her public-spirited intervention.

articles.title: Fire alert: the fake ‘Amazon TV stick’ that opens the door to fraudsters
articles.trailText: Two out of five illegal streamers have fallen prey to fraud, likely via a ‘modded’ USB stick that exposes users to data theft and cybercrime
articles.summary: Rogue ‘modded’ Amazon Fire Sticks sold online promise free sports and TV but embed malware that can steal credentials, bank details and facilitate identity fraud. A BeStreamWise survey found 40% of illegal streamers lost an average £1,700. Police and security experts say sticks install keyloggers and bypass antivirus, exposing home networks. Vendors face raids by Fact and prosecutions. Victims should remove devices, change passwords, enable multifactor authentication, run antivirus scans and report fraud to banks and Action Fraud.

articles.title: Relief for rail passengers as fare freeze in England announced for 2026
articles.trailText: Chancellor will confirm the measure, intended to help commuters on expensive routes, in her budget speech
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves has frozen regulated rail fares in England for 2026—the first such move in 30 years—to curb inflation, ease living costs and support growth amid expected tax rises to fill a £20 bn budget gap. The freeze, unveiled in the upcoming budget, spares commuters from a projected 4.8% rise, saving over £300/year on costly routes. Season tickets and peak/off-peak returns (over 1 bn journeys) are covered, while advance and first-class fares remain uncapped. Transport advocates and unions have welcomed the measure ahead of nationalised Great British Railways by 2027.

articles.title: Mortgage brokers say house buying at risk from surveyor ‘down valuing’
articles.trailText: London and the south-east said to be worst affected, with valuations often coming in at 10% below the agreed sale price
articles.summary: Mortgage surveyors have increasingly down-valued UK properties—often 5–15% below agreed sale prices, averaging around 10%—turning deals upside down, especially in London and the south-east. Brokers attribute the trend to pre-budget jitters and lender caution. Buyers forced to renegotiate, switch lenders or raise larger deposits; some purchases have collapsed after valuations cut a £3.1m home to £3m or dipped 17% in central London. RICS clarifies this reflects lender market-value assessments versus buyer valuations. New-build, unique rural properties and slower southern markets face the biggest markdowns, exacerbating regional price divergence and market uncertainty.

articles.title: Beware buy now, pay later temptation on Black Friday, debt charities warn
articles.trailText: Billions will be spent on credit over the discount weekend but experts say the payment option is ‘not risk-free’
articles.summary: Debt charities warn that Black Friday’s flood of buy now, pay later (BNPL) offers—used by over a third of Britons and accounting for £6.4 bn in 2025 spending—risks driving unprecedented debt. Use has leapt from 14% to 25% of UK adults, with 3 m missing payments in 2024, incurring fees and credit-score harm. Popular for £114 average transactions, especially fashion, BNPL’s instalment plans can overwhelm budgets. With no current regulation, the FCA will only bring BNPL under consumer credit rules from July 2026.

articles.title: How HMRC and insurance firms make bereavement even harder | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dr Susan Treagus spotted an error that could have cost her dearly, plus a letter on how to satisfy car insurance algorithms
articles.summary: Dr Susan Treagus reports that after notifying HMRC of her husband’s death, an algorithmic system misread two months of savings transfers for care fees and funeral costs as annual income, adding £62,000 to her occupational pension and pushing her into the higher tax bracket. She only discovered the error when her pension payments nearly halved and had to prompt HMRC for a manual correction. Another reader describes bypassing a “bereavement premium” car insurance rise by adding his distant son as a named driver, underscoring the absurd reliance on opaque algorithms at life’s most vulnerable moments.

articles.title: Households in Great Britain face surprise rise in energy bills from January
articles.trailText: Energy price cap for average dual fuel bill will increase to £1,758 a year, from £1,755 in the current quarter
articles.summary: Households face a 0.2% rise in Ofgem’s energy price cap from January, raising the average dual-fuel bill by £3 to £1,758—28p more per month—though still 2% below last year in real terms. Winter bills remain 50% above pre-Ukraine war levels. Ofgem warns wholesale prices are volatile; rising government levies lift the electricity cap 5.1% to 27.69p/kWh, while the gas cap falls 5.7% to 5.93p/kWh. Martin Lewis warns policy costs will climb into the 2030s and calls for a social tariff. National Energy Action urges funding levies via taxation. UK energy debt has reached £4.4bn and the government is considering scrapping VAT on electricity.

articles.title: Reeves urged to ‘grasp the nettle’ with wholesale reset of council tax
articles.trailText: Experts say chancellor should go further than rumoured plan to update value of homes in top three bands
articles.summary: Experts from the IFS, NEF and Resolution Foundation are urging Chancellor Rachel Reeves to use next week’s budget to fully revalue every English home—still based on 1991 values—instead of a limited update for bands F to H. Whitehall plans propose a £2,000–£3,000 annual levy on properties above a yet-to-be-finalized threshold (c. £1m–£2m), expected to yield under £1bn for the Treasury. Critics warn that a partial revaluation would complicate the system and perpetuate inequalities, calling for a comprehensive reset with protections such as a deferred-payment scheme for cash-poor older owners. This measure sits alongside Reeves’s wider fiscal package—prescription charge freeze, energy and cost-of-living relief—aimed at raising revenue without breaking manifesto tax pledges.

articles.title: Tell us: have you visited or worked at a UK ‘warm bank’?
articles.trailText: We want to hear people’s experiences with the rise of ‘warm spaces’ in the UK
articles.summary: As subzero Arctic air sweeps the UK, households face a 2% energy price-cap rise to £1,755 and £4.4bn supplier debt. In response, nearly 6,000 community ‘warm banks’—from libraries to charity-run hubs via Warm Welcome Spaces—have opened since 2022’s cost-of-living crisis. With winter 2024-25 underway, the Guardian is seeking firsthand accounts: have you visited, volunteered at or organised a warm space? Share why you took part, how it made you feel and your perspective on this rapid expansion of shelter from the cold.

articles.title: How could council tax change in budget – and who would be hardest hit?
articles.trailText: Critics say current system is a ‘dog’s dinner’ – with homes in Blackpool paying more than in one of London’s wealthiest boroughs
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves is weighing plans to reform England’s council tax – potentially doubling rates for band G and H properties or revaluing homes in tiers F–H and levying a surcharge on the top 300,000 by value. The Institute for Fiscal Studies estimates doubling would raise £4.2 billion by 2029–30, adding roughly £4,000 to bills on £750,000–£1.5 million homes. Critics call the bands outdated and regressive (“dog’s dinner”), noting huge regional disparities – Blackpool households pay more than Kensington – and warn the burden will fall on asset-rich, cash-poor middle-income families, especially in London and the south-east.

articles.title: Wanna hear the one about the low-paid dad who took paternity leave?
articles.trailText: MPs will tell ‘dad jokes’ in parliament to highlight ‘real joke’ of UK paternity leave, which is a class issue
articles.summary: MPs tell dad jokes in the Commons to spotlight the ‘real joke’ of UK paternity leave, paid at £187.18/week – the lowest in Europe. Dad Shift and HMRC data reveal 90% of leave claims come from top-half earners, only 5% of shared parental leave from lower earners, with stark regional divides. Campaigners warn low- and middle-income fathers are priced out of vital bonding time, framing paternity leave as a class issue. An 18-month government review is under way, and all-party MPs are urging reform.

articles.title: Wimbledon to get exemption from ticket resale crackdown for seats that can cost thousands
articles.trailText: Organisers claimed proposed ban on reselling tickets for more than face value would dent investment in facilities
articles.summary: Wimbledon’s All England Club secured a narrow exemption from the UK’s new ban on profit resale of event tickets, preserving its high-value five-year debenture programme. Debentures—transferable securities for Centre and No 1 Court seats plus hospitality—cost up to £116,000, fund facility maintenance and help keep general admission at £30 a day. Nearly 3,800 seats over 2026–30 are available via stockbroker or private sale, regulated by the FCA. The government’s crackdown targets for-profit reselling on platforms like Viagogo, but allows charity and debenture transfers. AELTC reported a £61.7m initial instalment from 2,520 debentures for 2026–30, using proceeds to service loans and fund development.

articles.title: A romance scam can be easy to fall for | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: One reader reveals that a man she trusted to make investments for her in bitcoin vanished with her money, in response to an article on romance scams
articles.summary: In January 2017 a UK-based interior designer met a man claiming to manage bitcoin investments. He professed London residence but lived in Wales, promised portfolio growth and encouraged her to invest inheritance post-summer. She entrusted £34,000, planning to clear her mortgage, but he repeatedly absented himself and reappeared to solicit more funds. On New Year’s Eve 2017 he vanished, leaving her with total losses. Police later confirmed he scammed others but closed her case in December 2023 for insufficient evidence.

articles.title: Ticket touts’ worst nightmare has finally come true in the UK
articles.trailText: Government has officially announced ban on reselling for profit, described by minister as ‘no-brainer’
articles.summary: The UK government has announced a ban on resale of tickets above face value, outlawing for-profit touting on specialist platforms and social media, with limited carve-outs (eg Wimbledon debentures). Business minister Kate Dearden called it a “no-brainer” amid cost-of-living concerns, seeking to save consumers £112m a year after exposés of bot-driven scalping and speculative selling. Enforced by an enhanced CMA with fines up to 10% of turnover, shares in StubHub plunged. Low-fee models like Twickets remain. Platforms warn of rising fraud without guarantees, but campaigners like FanFair Alliance dispute those claims, citing commissioned bias and border loopholes.

articles.title: Use smart tech, turn heat down, service boilers: how to save money on energy bills
articles.trailText: From turning down thermostats to make savings to installing reflectors to push warmth back into your home
articles.summary: Consumer finance experts advise homeowners to install timers or internet-connected smart thermostats (£60–£250, some with geofencing and multi-room control; energy supplier deals like Octopus/tado° up to 50% off) to schedule heating remotely. Lowering room setpoints from 22°C saves ~£90/year per degree. On combi boilers, reduce flow temperature from 75–80°C to ~60°C. Fit or adjust TRVs, add radiator reflectors behind panels, bleed radiators seasonally and arrange annual boiler servicing (£70–£110) for efficiency. Maintaining low background heat prevents damp and mould.

articles.title: Energy price cap in Great Britain expected to fall in January – but higher bills loom
articles.trailText: Cap on dual-fuel bills forecast to decrease by £22 to the equivalent of £1,733 a year for a typical household
articles.summary: Cornwall Insight forecasts that Great Britain’s dual-fuel price cap will dip by £22 (to £1,733/year) in January due to lower wholesale gas prices, but will then rise by £75 in April to fund grid and network upgrades linked to renewables. Cornwall’s Craig Lowrey warns non-wholesale costs – levies and policy charges – now drive bills and that pre-crisis levels remain high. Ahead of the autumn budget, a proposed cut to 5% VAT on energy may save £80/year, but upfront transition costs persist. Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit analyst Jess Ralston adds that upgrades will boost domestic renewables use and long-term stability.

articles.title: Amazon selling a tasteless Christmas baby outfit is Claus for concern
articles.trailText: The offensive listing seemed more than a mistake – it was a failure of corporate responsibility, says reader
articles.summary: An Amazon listing for infant to five-year-old Christmas outfits bore the phrase “Santa’s favourite ho,” prompting consumer outrage over apparent sexualized content targeted at children. Amazon immediately removed the product from UK and US sites for violating content guidelines, acknowledging its automated filters failed to catch the offensive slogan. Critics argue that a company of Amazon’s scale should proactively prevent exploitative or sexualized language in children’s merchandise, demanding stronger oversight, algorithmic safeguards, and proactive quality controls to protect parents and kids from inappropriate content.

articles.title: HMRC accused of being ‘cavalier’ with finances of child benefit claimants
articles.trailText: Thousands of parents had their payments stopped after faulty data suggested they had left the UK and not returned
articles.summary: HMRC halted child benefit payments for 23,795 parents flagged by flawed Home Office travel data as having emigrated, ultimately reinstating the eligibility of 3,673 after an investigative exposé. Dame Meg Hillier, chair of the Treasury select committee, branded HMRC ‘cavalier’ for dropping necessary cross-checks, including PAYE records, and summoned senior officials to answer 14 questions on the costly error. Many families—among them carers, medical patients and holidaymakers—were wrongly accused, facing invasive documentation demands. CEO John-Paul Marks apologised, pledged swift fixes, extended deadlines for proof of UK residence and promised strengthened safeguards to prevent repetition.

articles.title: UK bank and building society customer protection limit to rise to £120,000
articles.trailText: Increase of more than 40% from current figure of £85,000 will give more cover if financial firm goes bust
articles.summary: From 1 December the FSCS deposit guarantee limit jumps 41% from £85,000 to £120,000 per person per firm—the first rise in eight years—reflecting 3.8% inflation and consultation feedback. Temporary high-balance cover for life events climbs from £1 million to £1.4 million for six months, with payouts typically within seven days. The move may prompt savers to park more cash ahead of the chancellor’s 26 November budget, which could curb cash ISA allowances. Average UK savings stand at £16,067 (median £5,000–£6,000). PRA chief Sam Woods says it reinforces confidence.

articles.title: Reselling tickets for profit to be outlawed in UK government crackdown
articles.trailText: Touts, and ordinary consumers, will no longer be able to charge anything more than price at which they bought ticket
articles.summary: The UK government will ban reselling event tickets above their original purchase price under new legislation enforcing zero-profit secondary sales, with resale sites allowed limited service fees and liable under CMA enforcement. Banned are platforms like Viagogo/StubHub and social media exchanges; sellers must only list tickets they hold. The crackdown, backed by major artists and slated for next year’s King’s Speech, rejects licensing schemes, aims to curb touting, fraud and surging markups, though critics warn of driving trade underground.

articles.title: I have hit the barriers trying to get my accident claim settled with Autonet
articles.trailText: My van was hurtled into motorway barriers by a driver who did not stop and the vehicle is still being held in a compound along with the tools of my trade
articles.summary: A self-employed tradesman’s van was forced off the motorway and burned by a hit-and-run driver. Sixteen weeks after reporting the claim to Autonet, he endured repeated delays, poor communication, mounting storage fees, and confusion over a credit hire agreement that left him liable for rental costs. Autonet finally offered £1,835 for the write-off and half of £6,750 in expenses—later agreeing to top up to the full amount but including compensation in that sum—and restored his tools, only after 169 days, 30 emails, and potential exposure to legal action if a third-party insurer refuses to cover hire charges.

articles.title: Two-thirds of English councils have not prosecuted a single landlord in past three years
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Councils prosecuted just 64 landlords despite receiving 300,000 complaints from tenants in unfit homes
articles.summary: Between 2022 and 2024, two-thirds of English councils took no enforcement action against landlords despite 300,000 tenant complaints. Authorities prosecuted just 640 landlords, issued 4,702 civil penalty notices and raised £26.4m, with under 2% of complaints leading to formal action. Budget cuts have slashed enforcement teams by over a third since 2010. Although the Renters’ Rights Act (May 2026) pledges stronger powers, councils warn that a one-off £18m in ‘burdens funding’ falls far short of the sustained investment needed to protect renters and hold rogue landlords to account.

articles.title: ‘Ghost broking’: cut-price car insurance isn’t all it seems
articles.trailText: Scammers promise cheaper policies via ads on social media and AI-generated websites but the fake certificate leaves motorists uninsured
articles.summary: ‘Ghost broking’ fraud sells cut-price car insurance via social media ads and AI-generated sites, targeting 17–25-year-olds facing steep premiums (avg £3,100 in London). Scammers post low quotes (e.g. £586 for an Audi A3), collect personal data and bank transfers, then issue fake or tampered certificates. Aviva reports a 22% rise in cases this year, £2,000 average loss and one fraudster earning £150,000. Victims risk fines, bans, vehicle seizure and data exposure. Only use FCA-registered brokers and report scams to the Insurance Fraud Bureau or Action Fraud.

articles.title: ‘Bereavement penalty’: people who lost partners hit by insurance premium rises
articles.trailText: Campaigners claim AI algorithms are behind hefty increases in renewal quotes for home and car cover
articles.summary: Newly bereaved policyholders face startling insurance premium hikes—up to 15% on home and auto cover—after a partner’s death, a so-called ‘bereavement penalty.’ AI-driven risk models terminate joint-policy discounts, classing solo survivors as higher risk with no human explanation. Ageas and Swinton cases saw refunds and apologies but no systemic remedy, and widows still risk losing discounts at next renewal. Campaigners like Fairer Finance urge regulators to force clarity on opaque AI pricing, warning that grief-penalizing algorithms undermine consumer trust.

articles.title: People in the UK: tell us if you’ve borrowed money from friends or family
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from people in Britain who have turned to family or friends to borrow money instead of to banks, and how this has affected them
articles.summary: A Fair4All Finance survey of over 4,000 UK adults finds growing reliance on informal loans: 26% borrowed from family, 15% from friends and 25% used Buy Now Pay Later, often after bank rejections. One in four households couldn’t cover a £500 emergency without external help. Younger adults, families with children, zero-hours contract workers and those on lower wages are most likely to turn to loved ones. The Guardian seeks readers’ experiences of borrowing from friends or family and its impact on their finances and relationships.

articles.title: British music stars urge Starmer to tackle ‘pernicious’ ticket tout websites
articles.trailText: Radiohead, Dua Lipa and Coldplay among dozens of artists calling for cap on resale prices to stop exploitation of fans
articles.summary: Radiohead, Dua Lipa, Coldplay and 35 other British artists, who have sold over half a billion albums, have urged PM Keir Starmer to use the next king’s speech to impose a statutory cap (0–30% above face value) on ticket resale via platforms such as Viagogo and StubHub to curb “extortionate and pernicious” practices. The call follows Guardian and Which? exposés of bot bulk buying, “speculative selling” and extremes of up to £114,666 markups. While tout sites warn caps could spur unregulated fraud, signatories—including UK Music and FanFair Alliance—say limits would protect genuine fans and restore trust in live events. Government consultation ends imminently.

articles.title: Property experts urge Rachel Reeves to abolish ‘sin tax’ of stamp duty in budget
articles.trailText: Chancellor advised to replace levy with an annual property tax as Treasury considers overhaul of system
articles.summary: Property experts, led by TV presenter Kirstie Allsopp, have urged Chancellor Rachel Reeves to abolish stamp duty—labelled a ‘sin tax’—in the November budget, warning it punishes upward moves and stifles economic activity. MPs heard proposals to replace SDLT (levied on purchases above £125,000) with an annual property tax—0.54% on homes over £500,000, higher above £1m—to boost mobility and GDP. Zoopla data shows 40% of first-time buyers (80% in London) face an average £16,000 bill, while Taylor Wimpey links autumn sales dips to budget uncertainty. RICS reports further market cooling in October.

articles.title: UK to reconsider decision to deny Waspi women pension payouts
articles.trailText: Millions born in 1950s lost out because of government failings over changes to state retirement age, campaigners say
articles.summary: UK government will reconsider its December decision to deny compensation to as many as 3.6 million 'Waspi' women born in the 1950s after fresh evidence emerged ahead of a high court hearing due on 9 December. Campaigners say women lost thousands when the state pension age rose from 60 to 65 and 66 amid DWP maladministration. A 2024 PHSO report urged payouts of £1,000–£2,950 per person (total £3.5–£10.5 billion), but ministers, led by Rachel Reeves and Liz Kendall, rejected it to protect public services. Work and Pensions Secretary Pat McFadden will 'retake' the decision, though he cautioned it may still refuse redress.

articles.title: Tell us: have you moved to another country for your partner?
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from people who have moved to another country for their partner and the impact on your relationship
articles.summary: Consumer Money invites readers who have relocated abroad for a partner to share stories of challenges and relationship impact. Following an advice column by Annalisa Barbieri, they seek accounts from those who found the move difficult or regretful. Contributors should detail their origin and destination countries, timing of relocation, specific struggles faced and how the transition has changed their partnership dynamics. The feature will explore emotional, cultural and relational effects of love-driven migration. Submissions will inform an upcoming feature highlighting the emotional toll, cultural friction and adjustments of love-driven relocation, offering support and insights for prospective expat partners.

articles.title: Charging an electric car at home: what kit do you need and what is the cost?
articles.trailText: Installing a dedicated charger is good option – so too is switching to an EV tariff and charging at night or smartly
articles.summary: Guide to home EV charging covers hardware, installation costs and tariffs. A dedicated 7.4 kW AC charger (25–30 miles/hour) costs £800–£1,200 to fit, with a £350 grant for eligible homes; a smart meter unlocks time-of-use rates. Default tariffs average 26p/kWh, while specialist EV plans drop to 7–9p/kWh overnight (e.g. British Gas, E.ON, Scottish Power) or offer fully automated smart charging at ~7p/kWh (Octopus Go) or via £27.50–£30 monthly subscriptions. Off-street parking users benefit most, though on-street and lamppost chargers serve those without driveways.

articles.title: Metro Bank’s credit file markers are adding to the pain of our son’s death
articles.trailText: Bank refuses to remove late payment markers after we were twice late repaying our mortgage in last months of his life
articles.summary: After their 19-year-old son’s prolonged illness and death, a family fell behind on two mortgage repayments with Metro Bank. Metro placed late-payment markers on their credit file despite their prior clean record. When they applied to remortgage with Nationwide, the markers triggered refusal. Following a Guardian intervention, Metro agreed to remove the markers as a goodwill gesture, acknowledging their exceptional circumstances. Nationwide will review the case but remains concerned about depleted funds. The family is advised to rebuild finances before reapplying, and lenders urge customers to disclose personal hardships early to avoid credit penalties.

articles.title: UK divisions of ticket resale website Viagogo hit with £15m bill over tax shortfall
articles.trailText: Company already under scrutiny on ‘secondary ticketing’ amid outcry over touts using such platforms to exploit fans
articles.summary: HMRC has levied a combined £15m bill on two UK arms of Viagogo—VGL Services and IFOT Services—for underpaid duties linked to 2016–18 transfer-pricing practices. The firms, part of US-listed StubHub Holdings but legally separate, had provided technology and customer-service support to group entities and now face interest and late-payment charges. They dispute “double taxation,” have paid £5.5m so far, updated transfer-pricing policies and plan to seek treaty relief. This emerges as Viagogo confronts UK secondary-ticketing reforms and a CMA-mandated split from StubHub International.

articles.title: ‘Black Fraud Day’: shoppers warned over Black Friday scams
articles.trailText: Experts say to avoid unrealistic prices or requests for bank transfers, as AI makes it hard to tell real from fake sites
articles.summary: With Black Friday on 28 Nov fast approaching, UK authorities warn of a surge in AI-powered scams mimicking genuine retailers. NCSC’s Jonathon Ellison and cybersecurity firm Darktrace report a spike in malicious emails and fake sites offering unrealistically low prices, seeking bank transfers or crypto payments. Scam sites often lack privacy policies, use typosquatting URLs (eg, J0hn Lewis), and pressure shoppers with urgency. Which? advises checking domain legitimacy and price consistency; NCSC recommends forwarding suspicious emails to the Suspicious Email Reporting Service (7726 for texts) and using credit cards for consumer protection.

articles.title: Electric cars: could leasing a used EV help you afford one?
articles.trailText: With more secondhand cars available and salary sacrifice schemes offering extra savings, the lease option is taking off
articles.summary: In the UK used-EV leasing grew 166% in Q2 2025 as early-adopter models hit the secondhand market, offering affordable alternatives to £50k+ new EVs. Major lessors now offer two- to three-year leases with inclusive tax, maintenance and road tax; salary sacrifice schemes further cut costs by up to 45%, e.g., Mercedes EQA for £360 vs £570. Used Škoda Enyaq falls from £567 to £292 monthly. High-mileage drivers should note excess-mileage fees; credit checks apply. Employers like HSBC, BT and NHS trusts sponsor schemes, though self-employed can still lease via brokers like Carwow. At term end, returns incur minimal risk due to low EV breakdown rates and battery warranties.

articles.title: NS&I increases interest rates on fixed-term savings accounts
articles.trailText: Treasury-backed provider raises returns by up to 0.31 percentage points but experts say better deals are available
articles.summary: NS&I has raised interest rates on its one-, two-, three- and five-year fixed-term savings bonds by up to 0.31 percentage points (one year: 4.04→4.20%; two years: 3.85→4.10%; three years: 3.88→4.16%; five years: 3.84→4.15%), bucking the market’s downward trend. New and maturing customers can invest £500–£1 million with no early withdrawals, backed by a 100% Treasury guarantee. The move aims to meet government funding targets, but experts note better rates elsewhere—LHV Bank at 4.46%, JN Bank at 4.39%, Chetwood Bank at 4.35%—and Treasury discussions on cutting the annual ISA allowance continue.

articles.title: UK house prices rise at fastest rate since January 2025
articles.trailText: Halifax says October increase pushes average cost of home to £300k despite uncertainty over possible budget tax changes
articles.summary: In October UK house prices rose 0.6% month-on-month—the fastest pace since January 2025—pushing the average home cost to £299,862, reversing September’s 0.3% drop and beating forecasts. Annual growth hit 1.9% vs 1.5% expected. Mortgage approvals reached their highest level this year despite 4% fixed rates and squeezed disposable incomes, with many buyers opting for smaller deposits and longer terms. Uncertainty over possible stamp duty reforms on homes over £500k in Rachel Reeves’s upcoming budget has paused some activity but market resilience suggests a rebound once details are clear. Separately, Rightmove shares slid on slower profit growth projections, though AI investments promise long-term gains.

articles.title: How employers can help their staff stay in work | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to the government’s Keep Britain Working review that aims to tackle the growing worklessness crisis
articles.summary: Responses to the government’s Keep Britain Working review warn that focusing solely on occupational health and early intervention overlooks deeper issues: subsidised poor work—low pay, insecure hours, minimal support—and structural barriers locking out disabled people, older workers, parents and those with criminal records. Contributors urge tying public contracts to the real living wage and Good Work standards, equipping managers with training to make reasonable adjustments, and boosting schemes like Access to Work and skilled work coaches.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves considering pay-per-mile tax for electric vehicles in budget
articles.trailText: EV drivers would face 3p-a-mile charge on top of other road taxes to offset falling revenue from petrol and diesel cars
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves plans a 3p-per-mile levy on electric vehicles in this month’s budget, adding roughly £250 a year per driver to recoup a £20–30bn revenue shortfall as petrol duty revenues fall. After consultation, the scheme would apply from 2028 to about 4m EVs, equalising charges against the £600 annual petrol duty. Industry bodies like the SMMT and fleet firms warn it could undermine EV uptake, calling for more chargers, grants and incentives. Analysis shows EVs would still run £1,000 cheaper than petrol. Govt says it has invested £4bn in EV support.

articles.title: London Ulez auto pay blunders have triggered £11,445 in fines
articles.trailText: When account was suspended my brother-in-law was caught in debt as 200 penalty charge notices piled up
articles.summary: A London van driver with dyslexia and a chronic autoimmune disease racked up 200 PCNs after TfL suspended his Ulez auto-pay last December over a disputed charge, offering no clear alternative payment route. A surname misspelling made appeals fail as third-party claims. He paid £11,445 in fines, owes £1,400 with 70 penalties pending, and was denied an individual voluntary arrangement. Recorded calls reveal conflicting advice that blocked affordable plans. His mental strain led him to consider suicide. TfL then cancelled outstanding PCNs, reinstated auto-pay and will accept his prior payments to resolve the case.

articles.title: HMRC gave a refund from my tax account to fraudster making repayment claim
articles.trailText: I was in credit but HMRC handed £2,500 over to someone impersonating me on the phone, and says I’m in debt
articles.summary: London accountant EF was told he owed £2,500 after HMRC paid a fraudulent repayment to a scammer who impersonated him in January. Despite being in credit, his self-assessment account was left in arrears, triggering debt-collection letters. HMRC admitted it issued the cheque after a phone request using personal data “obtained elsewhere” but only corrected his balance and apologised following Guardian intervention. The case mirrors June’s £47m repayment fraud affecting 100,000 accounts and involves 13 other clients of EF’s firm.

articles.title: UK ‘to lose 600,000 workers to illness without better health support at work’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Royal Society of Public Health says ‘fundamental shift’ needed in how firms help those with health conditions
articles.summary: RSPH analysis warns that without a “fundamental shift” in employer health support, an extra 600,000 workers will leave the UK workforce over the next decade. Economically inactive adults could rise by 26% to 3.3m by 2035—equivalent to Bristol’s population—and cost the UK £36bn annually. The RSPH calls for a national health-and-work standard guaranteeing minimum employer support for musculoskeletal, mental and cardiovascular care, ahead of Sir Charlie Mayfield’s Keep Britain Working review. Experts say clearer standards, early intervention and specialist caseworker access can curb inactivity, boost productivity and reduce turnover. Government highlights its 10-year plan shifting from treatment to prevention as it awaits review recommendations.

articles.title: Weight loss jab warning: fraudsters’ fake products ‘could cause real harm’
articles.trailText: As texts and social media offer cheap offers, buying from unverified sellers can cause serious health problems
articles.summary: Fraudsters hawking cheap weight-loss injections via texts, messaging apps and faux social accounts are duping buyers into scams or dangerous fakes with unknown toxins. As Mounjaro prices soar, scammers lure buyers with low-cost jabs sans prescription. The MHRA warns illegal products from beauty salons, fake pharmacies or social media can harm health. Santander data shows losses from jab, pen, tablet and fat-dissolver scams more than doubled July–Sept, averaging £120 per victim. Scammers mimic brands, use urgency pitches and undercut legit prices. Advice: only buy prescription meds from General Pharmaceutical Council–registered pharmacies and verify authenticity.

articles.title: Even when unthinkable things were happening to me, my first instinct was to work. Am I addicted?
articles.trailText: It was only years later, when I heard the word workaholic being used seriously for the first time, that I wondered whether I had a problem
articles.summary: Guardian reporter Jenny reflects on years of compulsive workaholic behaviour, recounting filming a Norway asylum‐class documentary while pregnant and in pain, rushing back to work post‐miscarriage and appendicitis. She describes using work to numb grief—through repeated pregnancy losses, high‐pressure live broadcasts and seven‐day weeks during COVID. Surprised by the term “workaholism”, she investigates Workaholics Anonymous meetings, hearing stories from Jen, Sarah and others who liken work addiction to substance abuse. Behavioural researchers define workaholism as compulsive overworking causing life conflict, warning of anxiety, depression and health risks, yet distinguishing passion from pathological addiction.

articles.title: ‘Our hard work was worth it’: is a fixer-upper the best way to a dream home?
articles.trailText: Buying a place in need of renovation is one way of getting on the ladder – here’s how the cost of doing the work stacks up
articles.summary: First-time buyers now pay £229,094 vs £156,453 in 2015. About 7% of Zoopla listings are fixer-uppers, most 2-3 beds in Wales, SE England and Yorkshire. Jess and Rick Sowerby bought a 1930s semi in Rochdale for £155k in 2019 and spent £50k on an extension (£35k), rewire (£6k) and new doors (£2.5k), doing much DIY to save £15k. After 15 months they moved in; value rose to £350k. Experts advise structural surveys, 15–20% contingency, local amenity research, and highlight costs: decorating ~£2.5k, garden revamp ~£3.5k, extensions add 5–8% value, lofts 20%, solar 14%. Grants and green mortgages can help cover upgrades.

articles.title: Tell us: have you ever rented a room from a friend?
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from people who have had experiences of living with a “friendlord” in the past 5-10 years and find out the impact on their relationship
articles.summary: As housing pressures and living costs escalate, more homeowners are hosting lodgers, prompting tenants to rent spare rooms from friends—so-called “friendlords”—for cheaper, stable alternatives to the overheated rental market. While this setup can ease finances and deepen bonds, it can also blur boundaries, trigger conflicts over chores, privacy and money. The Guardian seeks first-person accounts from people who’ve lived with a friend as landlord in the past 5–10 years to describe how this arrangement affected your friendship—positively or negatively. Submissions may appear anonymously; see terms and privacy policy.

articles.title: Is a two-week half-term a good deal? Some parents in England aren’t so sure
articles.trailText: Growing number of schools are giving pupils and staff a fortnight off, but some parents complain of childcare costs
articles.summary: A growing number of English state and academy schools—from Nottinghamshire in 2019 to eight Unity primaries this year—are extending October half-term to two weeks (offset by a shorter summer or extra daily minutes) to give teachers rest, reduce holiday crowding and curb illness-related absences. But parents warn low-income, single and shift-working families face extra childcare (Coram: £179/week), food and energy bills, loss of free school meals and patchy holiday-club provision. Mismatched dates across schools worsen logistics. Some argue staggered breaks ease summer planning, though women shoulder most upheaval, and tour operators may hike “shoulder” rates despite initial cheaper deals.

articles.title: Older and younger renters: share your experiences
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from older renters over the age of 61, and aged 28 and younger, about their experiences
articles.summary: The Guardian calls on two demographic extremes—renters aged 28 or younger and those aged 61 and over—to recount experiences navigating England and Wales’ private rental market. Once synonymous with young “Generation Rent,” renting has soared across all ages: private renters climbed from 1.9m in 2001 to 5m in 2021, and 55+ households rose by 70% since 2010/11. Share reflections on unexpected long-term renting, prospects for ownership, affordability struggles, landlord issues or rental horror stories. Contributors encouraged to detail cost pressures, community impacts, eviction anxieties and aspirations. Submit via the online form; see terms and privacy policy.

articles.title: New AI-powered anti-scam tool wins praise from UK fraud minister
articles.trailText: Starling tool can scan images of items and ads on sites such as Facebook Marketplace, eBay, Vinted and Etsy
articles.summary: Starling Bank launched Scam Intelligence, a UK-first AI tool built with Google’s Gemini on Google Cloud, to help shoppers vet marketplace listings (Facebook Marketplace, eBay, Vinted, Etsy) and payment requests. Users upload images, listings or message screenshots; the tool flags signals such as too-low prices, generic/low-quality photos, bank account–seller mismatches, refusal to use platform escrow, and urgency/pressure. Praised by fraud minister Lord Hanson, it lifted payment cancellations 300% in testing and claims 90% image scam-indicator detection. Debuting at a Las Vegas fintech event, it targets prevalent purchase scams (now at a record since 2020). In-app, opt-in, and used most for tickets and trainers.

articles.title: Consumers: tell us how you feel about large quantities of emails from brands
articles.trailText: Whether it’s transactional confirmation messages, special offer alerts, abandoned cart reminders or newsletters, we’d like to hear what people make of the steady influx of emails from brands
articles.summary: Callout seeking consumer views on the surge of brand emails. A single online purchase can trigger a dozen messages: order, processing, courier handover, dispatch, transit and delivery confirmations, plus multiple review prompts. Beyond transactional notices, companies send welcome emails, newsletters, special-offer alerts, abandoned-cart reminders and other unsolicited marketing. The editors ask how you feel about this steady influx, whether you’ve tried to avoid receiving such emails, and if it’s changed your shopping habits. Or do you appreciate frequent updates and tracking? Readers are invited to share experiences, coping tactics, and any impact on purchasing behavior.

articles.title: The best Halloween money-saving tricks, from DIY costumes to cheap treats
articles.trailText: From deals on sweets to ways of getting into the spooky mood cheaply or for free
articles.summary: With sweets rising (Haribo Starmix 22-pack at Tesco £3 vs £2.35 in 2024; chocolate +18.1% y/y), cut costs by bulk-buying individually wrapped treats and checking count/kg: B&M Popping Candy 36/£1; Morrisons Swizzels 16/£1.25 (£1 More Card); Asda Haribo 22/£1.98. DIY costumes/decor from wardrobe/cardboard; Tesco glow sticks 15/£1.50; reuse buys (Cancer Research spider doorstop £6.99) and thrift in November. Host instead of £34-a-head outings: apples 6/99p (Asda) for bobbing; haunt your lounge with free SFX apps. Pumpkins: Sainsbury’s £2 (£1.75 Nectar), Asda £1.88; Tesco munchkins 60p/2 for £1; Aldi 42p; free patches (Orway Porch, Doddington Hall, South Farm). Films cheap via ad tiers £5.99 (Netflix/Disney+), Sky Store sales, Cineworld £5.99, Time Out popup £6.66.

articles.title: Our cars were towed away for repair and are being held to ransom
articles.trailText: They are hostage in a repair shop and won’t be released over a debt that has nothing to do with the vehicles
articles.summary: After Bidfood trucks hit their cars (Jan and Jun), victims BN and NC had vehicles towed by Bidfood’s claims manager VMS Global to Cobra Coachworks. Though repairs were completed and paid for, Cobra withheld both cars—plus about 23 others incl Iceland—citing an unrelated £189,000 arrears dispute with VMS. Owners got no updates, kept paying PCP, and BN received five Ulez PCNs as his car appeared driven across London. VMS only threatened an injunction after press intervention. Bidfood, saying cases weren’t escalated, terminated VMS. Police called it civil. After delays, BN’s car returned with 46 extra miles; NC’s came back after ‘lost keys’.

articles.title: Private rent in Britain now swallows 44% of the average wage
articles.trailText: Monthly cost jumps to record £1,385 outside London, and £2,736 in the capital, with hotspots showing hefty rises
articles.summary: Rightmove Q3 data show Great Britain’s advertised private rents hit records: £1,385 pcm outside London; £2,736 in the capital—the third straight quarterly high. Despite 5% annual pay growth, rent now consumes 44% of the average wage (40% five years ago). Supply is improving but tight: available rentals +9% year on year, still 23% below 2019; new listings just +1%. Hotspots: Fulwood, Preston +32% (£970→£1,284); Keighley and Frome +27%; Newquay +23%; Gainsborough +22%; Burgess Hill, Billericay, Paisley ≥17%. Landlords face higher stamp duty, possible tax changes, and a renters’ rights bill awaiting royal assent; tenant demand has eased amid uncertainty.

articles.title: Girl boss or tradwife? An economist on how a workforce built for men has failed women
articles.trailText: In her new book Having it All, Corinne Low outlines how stubborn expectations around work and home fail to accommodate working women
articles.summary: Wharton economist Corinne Low’s Having It All (UK: Femonomics) blends data and memoir to explain "the squeeze" on working mothers: workplaces built around men plus intensive parenting norms and stagnant male domestic labor. She links women’s workforce entry to 1970s unilateral divorce laws, arguing home production was undervalued and human capital became protection. Low critiques Lean In/#Girlboss for ignoring structures, warns tradwife nostalgia is risky, and notes dating/fertility timelines. Policy fix: paid maternity leave; personal fix: define your "utility function" and negotiate at home. Her arc—Amtrak pumping, Covid squeeze, divorce, move to Philly, au pair, then tenure—shows trade-offs.

articles.title: ‘Crash for cash’: moped riders target your insurance details
articles.trailText: Fraudulent insurance policies are being taken out by scammers using details you do not need to hand over
articles.summary: UK insurers warn of a moped "crash for cash" scam where riders engineer low-speed bumps, then pressure motorists to hand over photos of driving licences or insurance papers. Those details are used to open policies and file bogus claims; IFB logged 1,100 fraudulent motor policies between summer 2024 and March, mainly in London and the Home Counties (Chelmsford, Hertford, Rickmansworth, St Albans). Risk rises in winter. Targets include women alone/with children and older drivers. Guidance: exchange only name, address and registration; refuse document photos; gather plate/dashcam/witness info; alert insurer and police; report via IFB Cheatline; consider Cifas Protective Registration (£30/2 years).

articles.title: Young first-time buyers forced into ‘nature deserts’, UK data shows
articles.trailText: Exclusive: High cost of homes near green spaces may be deepening health inequalities, says wildlife coalition
articles.summary: Young UK first-time buyers are being funnelled into "nature deserts" as cheaper homes cluster where green space is scarce, says Wildlife and Countryside Link (WCL). Its ONS-based 2023 regression finds that for each square metre of green space lost per person, 494 more first-time buyers cluster there. Parks cut anxiety/depression ~20%; living >800m away was linked to worse wellbeing in Covid, deepening inequalities. WCL says the planning and infrastructure bill could worsen loss by allowing building on protected sites and off-site offsets, even in other counties. Charities, including the National Trust, back part-three amendments to guarantee green/blue space, protect existing parks, and require nature in new developments. One-third lack a 15-minute walk; deprived areas are twice as likely to be nature-deprived.

articles.title: ‘My big shop used to cost £100, now it’s £150’: readers recount their shock at supermarket food bills
articles.trailText: We hear your stories of how you balance the family finances, from buying own brands to cutting right back on weekly shop
articles.summary: UK shoppers report steep grocery bills despite easing inflation: Nikki (Aberdeenshire) spends £220+ a week vs £135 pre‑2020, worsened by costly gluten‑free items. Viral Aldi post: £98 for four bags, no booze. ONS: CPI 3.8%; food inflation 4.5% (Aug 5.1%), yet shops ~30% pricier than 2022. Food Foundation: 1 in 7 households with children food‑insecure; 64% cut fruit, 50% veg. Readers switch to own‑label (Heinz beans 4‑pack £3.90 vs £1.60); own‑label share 51.2%, premium ranges +10%+. Anne’s big shop ~£150; coffee £5→£8.35. Price rises: beef mince 500g £3.62→£5.24; Lurpak £3.75→£4.69. IFS: poorer hit hardest; BRC cites £7bn extra taxes; Tesco profits £2.9bn‑£3.1bn. Tactics: swap meats, meal‑plan, chase points.

articles.title: Surge in UK savings lost to investment scams, with fake crypto thought to top the list
articles.trailText: Banking industry data shows £629m was stolen in six months from fraud that included gold, wine and property
articles.summary: UK Finance data show UK consumers lost £629m to fraud in H1 2025, up 3% YoY; investment-scam losses jumped 55% to £97.7m (>£500k/day), with fake crypto leading. Scams often start via social-media ads/deepfake videos (e.g., Martin Lewis), small £250 stakes, spoofed trading dashboards, then 'fees/taxes' blocking withdrawals; one Georgia-based ring stole £9m. Romance-scam losses rose 35%; contactless card fraud up 27%. Stop Scams UK convened banks, telecoms, tech—attended by Andrew Bailey and fraud minister Lord Hanson—urging crypto-sector participation, cross-sector data sharing, and accountability in the government’s fraud strategy. Industry groups demand tougher duties for social platforms/phone firms.

articles.title: Rats! How to banish rodents, bedbugs and other pests from your home
articles.trailText: It’s best to prevent their arrival in the first place – but here’s how to deal with unwelcome visitors if they appear
articles.summary: Stop pests by prevention: seal all entry points (mice squeeze through 6–10mm) with wire wool/metal covers, including around pipes/air bricks. Keep bins, surfaces, cupboards spotless; store food in rodent‑proof containers; fix leaks. Check lofts for rats. For bedbugs, inspect mattress seams, headboards, divans, slats for live bugs, shed skins, black spotting, eggs; check hotels and secondhand furniture; keep luggage away from beds. Renters: notify landlord/council. Humane/DIY: peppermint oil (use cautiously), cinnamon, ultrasonic plugs, humane traps baited with chocolate/peanut butter; don’t move infested beds. Pros: evidence‑led survey, proofing, traps; typical UK rat/mice job ~£180 (2 visits). Bedbugs: avoid OTC sprays/smoke bombs; use chemical+steam or heat >55C; vacuum temporarily.

articles.title: Millions in households in England and Wales are stuck in the red, says charity
articles.trailText: Citizens Advice says 4 million people spending more on essentials than they earn amid ever-increasing bills
articles.summary: Citizens Advice warns 4 million people in England and Wales are in negative budgets—spending more on essentials than they earn—with another 580,000 left with only £50 a month. Using ONS data and client records, it finds private renters and single parents most exposed; half of debt clients are now in the red. Average deficit: £343 in 2024-25, rising to £396 in 2025-26; average household debt £9,963. Energy bills hit £1,755/yr; August food inflation 5.1% (butter, coffee, chocolate, beef up); rents taking larger income shares. CA urges targeted utility bill support, higher Local Housing Allowance, ending the two-child benefit limit, and criticises government inaction and Labour’s delivery.

articles.title: Travelodge guest suffers sleepless night as hotel says it is ‘overbooked’
articles.trailText: Customers told there is no room and sent miles away late at night, or forced to spend the small hours on the street
articles.summary: Travelodge faces complaints of overbooking. A 77-year-old Oxford guest (MAG) prepaid; after a 10pm confirmation call, she arrived to find five others displaced and was sent 21 miles to a service‑station hotel. She incurred £63 extra and was refunded £118 and a voucher. Despite a policy not to relocate lone women, Travelodge later cited a “maintenance issue.” JF in Cardiff was diverted 12 miles after staff said rooms were “trashed,” later rebranded a water leak; he got a refund and voucher. In Brighton, TA spent hours outside during blaring alarms, initially offered £60. Travelodge says overbooking is rare and safety is the priority.

articles.title: The Beijing courier who went viral: how Hu Anyan wrote about delivering parcels – and became a bestseller
articles.trailText: Like so many others, his days have been spent in the gig economy, moving from one precarious job to another, often tied to a gruelling 996 shift pattern. He discusses the harsh realities of modern working life in China, and far beyond
articles.summary: Chinese writer Hu Anyan’s memoir I Deliver Parcels in Beijing, a 2023 bestseller, arrives in English (Allen Lane, 28 Oct). It chronicles his 2018–19 courier stint: 1.6 yuan (≈£0.17) per parcel, a delivery every four minutes, on‑site try‑ons, liability for losses, and time math that made a pee cost 1 yuan and lunch (20 minutes) 10 yuan. Now 47, Hu has held 19 jobs in 20 years—996 retail, 7pm–7am logistics (top 5,000 yuan), bakery apprentice, security guard, designer—reflecting China’s gig precarity and ≈300m migrant workers. A 2020 viral blog launched his literary career. Readers—and state media—embrace its humane critique amid youth joblessness and “lying flat.”

articles.title: Housing market slows amid fears Reeves will increase property taxes
articles.trailText: Post-summer bounce in activity fails to materialise as buyers and sellers, in the south especially, opt to ‘wait and see’
articles.summary: UK housing activity cooled as budget jitters rise over Chancellor Rachel Reeves potentially raising property taxes. Rightmove says September year-on-year new buyer enquiries and new listings fell 5%; the usual post-summer bounce is absent, especially in southern England. Average asking prices for new listings rose 0.3% (£1,165) in October to £371,422, below the 10-year October average (+1.1%). Speculation includes a levy on sales over £500k, curbing CGT relief on primary residences above £1.5m, and a new high-value council tax band. Knight Frank says demand is wavering despite stable mortgage rates; lenders, buyers and sellers are pausing. Treasury touts pro-building reforms and fiscal balance.

articles.title: Suspected scam investment firms ‘exploiting Trustpilot review system’
articles.trailText: Fake reviews, forged certificates and stolen corporate identities being used to lure victims, KwikChex finds
articles.summary: Verification firm KwikChex says scam investment outfits are gaming Trustpilot with coordinated five‑star reviews, forged incorporation certificates, cloned sites and stolen corporate identities, even posing as an SRA‑regulated recovery law firm. Networks boosted linked firms and attacked rivals; red flags included virtual offices. Trustpilot launched probes, removed reviews and a page, added alerts; 7.4% of 2024 reviews were removed (6.1% in 2023), mostly via AI. Crypto‑Benefits247 fell from 4.7 to 2.8 after flags; FCA warning; one victim lost £65k. Oakvests Crypto misused another firm’s CEO video; rating to 3.2. Quantum Recovery Law Group drew an SRA scam alert; profile removed. KwikChex urges dropping “verified” and the “find a company you can trust” slogan.

articles.title: Energy clubs offer chance to reduce electricity bills by up to 30%
articles.trailText: Energy Local, a non-profit, creates a way for customers to team up with green projects to get a better deal
articles.summary: Energy Local, a non-profit, creates cooperative energy clubs that match households’ half-hourly usage with nearby renewables via smart meters and a special tariff, letting members buy local power below standard rates while generators earn above wholesale. Typical savings: 10%-30%. There are 36 clubs nationwide. Examples: Bridport, Dorset (about 60 members using a farmer’s wind turbine, saving 10%-25%); Brixton’s Roupell Park (around 18 homes on community-owned solar). Members switch to a partner supplier, still pay standing charges, and pay higher rates when local output is low, incentivizing load shifting. An online dashboard forecasts local generation. Clubs complement, not replace, the grid, amid rising bills (price cap now £1,755).

articles.title: UK students: have you been targeted by scammers?
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from UK students about their experiences of being targeted by criminals trying to steal their money
articles.summary: NatWest’s survey of 5,000 UK undergraduates reports 57% have been scammed or had near-misses, with young adults losing an average £300 to fraud in the past year; one in four encountered bank-impersonation attempts. The Home Office has launched an awareness campaign. The Guardian is seeking UK students’ first-hand accounts of scam targeting—especially bank impersonation—including what tactics were used, amounts at stake, and outcomes. Submissions will inform coverage on student safety, fraud trends, prevention, and support needs during the academic year.

articles.title: Energy bills likely to rise by 20% in next four years, says Britain’s biggest supplier
articles.trailText: MPs told that even if wholesale prices plummet, consumers face higher bills owing to costs of government policies
articles.summary: Octopus Energy told MPs household bills are on track to rise ~20% over four years even if wholesale electricity halves, driven by escalating non-commodity costs: grid/network upgrades, system operation and low-carbon scheme levies. Director Rachel Fletcher urged delaying non-urgent investments and imposing budgetary controls. E.On UK's CEO said bills would be similar even at zero wholesale. Government rejected this, citing wholesale gas still 75% above pre-2022 and backing clean-energy build-out. Current cap: £1,755 (~£500 above pre-war), with only ~£200 from wholesale; network charges £396 (+£140 in 4 years), policy costs £215 (+£86). Suppliers warned phasing out gas plants won't fix bills without tackling these drivers.

articles.title: Use trials, threaten to cancel: how to get a good deal on UK TV streaming services
articles.trailText: There are many options for getting better prices on Netflix, Amazon Prime, Apple TV+ and Sky’s Now TV
articles.summary: How to cut UK streaming bills: use free trials (Prime 30 days; Apple TV+ and Hayu 7 days; Netflix none), rotate subscriptions, and avoid duplicates. Choose ad tiers (Disney+ £5.99 vs £9.99 ad-free; Netflix with ads £5.99) and skip unneeded 4K/multi-screen. Leverage bundles: Club Lloyds 12-month Disney+ (ads) free, Barclays Apple TV+, O2/EE promos, 3 months Apple TV+ with Apple devices; Prime £8.99/m or £95/y. Share plans: Netflix Premium £18.99 with extra members £4.99/£5.99; Disney+ add-ons £4.99/£5.99; Apple TV+ family sharing. Prefer Now over Sky; grab annual/long deals (Paramount+, Hayu; Now Entertainment £4.99; Now Sports £28). Students: Apple Music + TV+, Prime Student. Start cancellation to trigger 30–50% retention; e.g., Now Sports £34.99→£20. Or pause for iPlayer/Channel 4/ITVX/5.

articles.title: People in the UK: have you been shocked at food prices in the supermarket?
articles.trailText: Have you noticed how much less you’re getting for your money while buying groceries than you did previously?
articles.summary: Guardian callout seeks UK shoppers’ experiences of rising grocery costs, inviting photos of weekly shops showing how little £50–£100 now buys. Official figures cited: food price inflation increased for a fifth consecutive month, from 4.9% in July to 5.1% in August. Readers are asked to share what their weekly shop costs now, which food and drink items have seen the biggest increases, and any products they’ve stopped buying. Submissions can include shopping bag photos and total spend. A web form is provided for contributions, with a help link, and references to the outlet’s terms of service and privacy policy.

articles.title: MG wants us to pay £500-plus to remedy rogue electric car
articles.trailText: After charging, there was a power system malfunction but MG closed the case and insisted a safety check was at our own expense
articles.summary: An MG5 EV allegedly went out of control after motorway charging: it wouldn’t power down, then surged forward when put in reverse, failed to brake, hit the AA van, and spun its wheels. AA deemed it unsafe, transported it, and covered £2,500 repairs. The dealer found no fault and sought £500 for investigation; MG initially closed the case despite the warranty. After press intervention, MG performed further checks using multiple public chargers and a 25-mile test, found no malfunction, and waived fees. With similar incidents reported, the owner lost confidence after six weeks and plans to sell.

articles.title: BA stalls over paying out £220 flight compensation
articles.trailText: First it said it was bad weather so the rules exempted it, then that it was an operational issue
articles.summary: British Airways cancelled a Tui package flight home from Switzerland, rebooking ~40 passengers 36 hours later, then refused the £220 per person compensation due under EU/UK Regulation EC 261/2004, citing adverse weather. Yet its insurer letter gave “operational reasons,” blocking both airline payout and insurance. BA later claimed weather‑displaced crew caused knock‑on disruption, and ignored questions on timings. Bott & Co say such knock‑ons aren’t “extraordinary circumstances,” so compensation is owed. After the case went to ADR body CEDR and the Guardian challenged apparent stalling, BA paid; other affected passengers may still lack redress.

articles.title: Generational shift as millennials make up half of new buy-to-let investors in England and Wales
articles.trailText: Surprise finding by Hamptons shows age group comprises 50% of all new shareholders in firms set up this year
articles.summary: Millennials now comprise 50% of new shareholders in buy-to-let companies in England and Wales, up from 40% five years ago, per Hamptons/Companies House. Despite April’s surcharge rising to 5% (from 3%), landlords bought 11.3% of homes in Q3, near last year’s level. Hamptons expects millennials to form 33,395 BTL companies in 2025, over twice 2020. Investor buying has shifted north: London/SE/SW/E now 34% of purchases (50% in 2016); the North East’s share is 28.4% versus London’s 8%. New-let rents fell 0.3% YoY to £1,398; London −2.7%, inner London −4.6% to £2,766. BTL firms are now the UK’s largest business type; Gen Z incorporations overtook boomers.

articles.title: ‘£850 to skip the queue’: how scammers are exploiting driving test delays
articles.trailText: Criminals claim there are ways to get a licence without exams. Accepting puts you at risk of identity theft and even prison
articles.summary: Scammers are exploiting GB driving-test backlogs (avg 22 weeks; London 24) by selling licences without exams via social media/WhatsApp. They claim DVSA/DVLA insiders will upload fake passes, charging £500-£850 (eg £200 upfront; £740 auto; £850 manual), request provisional-licence screenshots, bank transfers, and personal details. DVLA/DVSA deny involvement, warn documents are counterfeit; possession can mean up to 10 years' jail. DVSA says 668,128 practical tests were booked at end-Sept (579,138 a year earlier). TSB reports losses tied to lesson/test fraud doubled; average loss £244; almost all scams run on social platforms. TikTok banned three accounts; Instagram removed two.

articles.title: What price loyalty? UK supermarket cards rated
articles.trailText: As prices rise, we look at whether schemes such as Tesco’s Clubcard and Sainsbury’s Nectar are a good deal
articles.summary: With grocery inflation high, UK supermarket loyalty cards now feel essential. Mintel says 76% use one; Tesco has 24m Clubcards, Nectar 27m. CMA’s review of 50,000 loyalty offers found 92% genuine savings but urged shoppers to compare. Ratings: Tesco Clubcard 8/10—1pt/£1=1p, 2x partner rewards, 10k weekly Clubcard Prices (claimed £375/yr), strong personalisation; non-members pay more. Sainsbury’s Nectar 8/10—1pt=0.5p, 500+ partners, Nectar Prices + personalised offers claim £450/yr (323+169). Asda Rewards 4/10—app missions build a cashpot; savings delayed. Lidl Plus 7/10—app-only weekly/personalised deals, Coupon Plus, self-scan; digital exclusion. Co-op 5/10—£1 one-off join, members’ prices, two weekly offers. Waitrose 6/10—vouchers, free hot drinks, ‘little treats’ trial. M&S Sparks 4/10—personalised/clothing perks, birthday freebies. Morrisons More 6/10—points (5,000=£5), fewer upfront deals, expiry. Which?: Aldi cheapest; big baskets still cheaper at Asda than Tesco+Clubcard.

articles.title: TikTok influencers fuelling parallel market for unlicensed weight-loss drug
articles.trailText: Guardian finds a thriving trade on Telegram for retatrutide, which is still in clinical trials and illegal to sell
articles.summary: Guardian probe finds TikTok influencers and Telegram sellers driving a UK parallel market for retatrutide, Eli Lilly’s unapproved phase‑3 “triple G” weight‑loss shot targeting GLP‑1, GIP, glucagon; early trials show up to 25% loss. Influencers (Jon Kluth, @MappyMyGains, @clairejoy86) promote “reta,” share codes, push DMs; Telegram channels (to 9,000 members) post before/after pics, injection guides, then route buyers to WhatsApp, promising 24–48‑hour delivery. Offers: powder vials or prefilled pens (~£160/20mg). Sales are illegal under Human Medicines Regulations 2012; some label it “research chemical.” TikTok says it removed content; Telegram cites moderation. Clinicians warn of counterfeits, contamination, misdosing; Mounjaro price rises seen as driver. Lilly: not approved anywhere; sales risky.

articles.title: David Lammy rules out charging workers for employment tribunal claims
articles.trailText: Justice secretary says right to challenge unfair work behaviour is core to Labour’s work plan after union backlash
articles.summary: Justice secretary and deputy PM David Lammy ruled out reintroducing fees for employment tribunal claims after union backlash to a floated plan in spending-review talks, calling free access vital to Labour’s ‘make work pay’ agenda. Fees were imposed in 2013 by the Tory–Lib Dem coalition and struck down in 2017 by the Supreme Court after a Unison case. TUC’s Paul Nowak welcomed the decision. Conservatives under Rishi Sunak had proposed a £55 fee. With a 45,000-case backlog and judge shortages, the MoJ is hiring 36 tribunal judges this year and 50 next year. Labour’s employment bill may raise case volumes; business groups warn of costs.

articles.title: People in the UK: tell us how much money you have managed to save
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from people in Britain how much they have in savings, and to what extent this money, or lack thereof, has been shaping their plans and lifestyles
articles.summary: Callout: UK readers asked to share how much they’ve saved and how savings affect plans. After a record savings rate in the 2020 lockdown, high rates and the cost of living crisis have pushed many to dip into reserves; unauthorised Lifetime ISA withdrawals rose 139% from 2020/21 to 2023/24. Finder: average savings £16,067 in 2025, but 39% have ≤£1,000, 23% ≤£200, and 16%—about 8.4m adults—have none; among millennials and Gen X, 18% have none. Questions: Is your emergency fund adequate? Have you paused contributions, withdrawn to cover bills, relied on debt, or prioritised saving over non-essentials? Describe how your savings, or lack of them, shape lifestyle and plans.

articles.title: Ovo pricing change could double charging costs for some EV owners
articles.trailText: Customers on Charge Anytime deal who drive fewer than 700 miles a month say they will be left with higher bills
articles.summary: From 4 Nov, Ovo will end its 7p/kWh any-time Charge Anytime tariff, raising ad-hoc charging to 14p/kWh unless EV drivers take a new monthly bundle (from £27.50 for ~700 miles) that also includes a ~600-mile public-charging voucher. Allowances don’t roll over and vouchers aren’t accepted by all networks. Low-mileage users (<700 miles/month) expect higher bills; comparisons are harder because bundles are priced by miles, not kWh. Competing suppliers offer <9p/kWh off-peak night rates. Eligibility still requires an Ovo supply, smart meter and compatible charger. Consumer groups warn of deterrence to EV adoption. Ovo, serving 4m homes, denies financial motives despite Ofgem resilience shortfall; it pitches simplicity and waives exit fees.

articles.title: Junior Isas: how to turn £50 a month into £18,000 for your child at age 18
articles.trailText: Learn the rules, compare accounts and save steadily – five ways to make saving more efficient (and often more lucrative) for your offspring
articles.summary: A UK Junior Isa (Jisa) is a tax-free account for children with a £9,000 yearly cap; funds are locked until 18. A child can hold one cash and one stocks & shares Jisa; CTFs must be transferred. Anyone can contribute; saving outside a Jisa triggers the £100 parental-interest tax rule. Shop around on cash rates (Coventry BS currently leads) and switch if cut. Despite 42% of 2022-23 inflows going to cash, investing typically wins: over 10 years £1,000 in a global tracker grew to £3,284 vs £1,141 in cash (ex-fees). Multi-asset funds can smooth volatility; cash risks inflation erosion. At 16 teens can manage; at 18 they control or transfer to an adult Isa. Save £50/month at 5% ≈ £18,050; maxing £9k/year ≈ £265,851.

articles.title: UK house price growth slows as buyers show caution before budget
articles.trailText: Cost of a typical home fell £794 to £298,184 in September after 0.2% monthly rise in August, says Halifax
articles.summary: Halifax said UK house prices rose 1.3% y/y in September, the weakest since Apr 2024 and below a Reuters forecast of 2.2%. Prices fell 0.3% m/m (-£794) to £298,184, reversing August’s 0.2% rise. Average first-time buyer homes cost £236,811, up 1.7% y/y. Halifax cites easing mortgage rates and wage growth but lingering uncertainty. Buyers appear cautious ahead of Rachel Reeves’s 26 Nov budget, with a mooted stamp duty replacement for sales over £500k. BoE held rates at 4%; inflation 3.8% in Aug. Nationwide reported +0.5% m/m. Taylor Wimpey and Foxtons flag steady momentum but softer confidence.

articles.title: Barclays sent me on wild goose chase trying to close sick mum’s account
articles.trailText: She is from mainland Europe and I have to shut her UK banking now she is in a care home abroad
articles.summary: A UK-based daughter tried to close her dementia-stricken mother’s Barclays account after moving her back to mainland Europe and being appointed legal guardian by a foreign court. Barclays issued shifting demands—original order, £650 translation, then £150 certified translation plus apostille—followed by confusion over whether to apostille the original or the translation, prompting costly travel and tears in-branch. After Guardian intervention, Barclays provided clear instructions, agreed to close the account, and paid £150 goodwill, apologising. The article highlights poor processes for foreign guardianship. A parallel case: Halifax wrongly demanded an Alzheimer’s patient’s signature to remove him from a joint account; it relented and paid £350 to LC from Oxfordshire.

articles.title: Holiday horrors: Airbnb and Booking.com users battle for refunds as stays go wrong
articles.trailText: In a Consumer Champions special, Anna Tims tackles online rental disasters, from a tree collapsing on to a cottage to being trapped in a flat
articles.summary: Guardian Consumer Champions details refund battles with Airbnb and Booking.com. In Provence, a 100-year-old oak crushed an Airbnb cottage and hire car; after 10 weeks of AI auto-replies, Airbnb said refunds were the host’s call; the £931 guests got a full refund plus £500 voucher only after inquiries; the host cited €5,000 repairs. Booking.com cases: Barcelona guests trapped by a failed door lock lost most of a day; a €250 deposit was withheld and a €446 refund refused. A London renter found an empty key safe, spent £123 on a hotel. Refunds came only after Guardian intervention. Which? says Booking.com’s “relevant” review default hides recent scam warnings; Booking.com says users can sort reviews and it relies on hosts. Contracts bind guests to hosts, complicating redress; Martyn James urges regulation. UK DMCC Act 2024 requires “professional diligence” and toughens CMA penalties.

articles.title: Water bills: millions of households in England could face even bigger rises
articles.trailText: CMA poised to give verdict after appeal by five firms for permission to increase bills higher than allowed by Ofwat
articles.summary: Millions of households in England may face larger water-bill increases as the CMA readies provisional rulings on appeals by Anglian, Northumbrian, Southern, Wessex and South East (14.7m customers) to exceed Ofwat's December settlement, which already lifts average bills 36% to £597 by 2030. S&P says firms seek up to £2bn extra capex atop £104bn. Analysts see CMA boosting allowances, notably for Southern, South East and Wessex, citing higher cost-of-equity benchmarks than Ofwat's. Thames Water paused its appeal amid restructuring but could resume. Decisions due early October pose political risks for new environment secretary Emma Reynolds as ministers eye replacing Ofwat and sewage fixes may take 15 years.

articles.title: UK ministers aim to speed up homebuying by four weeks
articles.trailText: Proposed government overhaul of house purchase process looks at shifting some costs from buyers to sellers
articles.summary: UK ministers unveiled proposals to cut homebuying timelines by four weeks by shifting some upfront costs/information duties from buyers to sellers and estate agents. Sellers would be compelled to supply key data (property condition, leasehold charges) before listing, with MHCLG estimating first-time buyers save £710 on average. A UK-wide consultation, launched under Angela Rayner and now led by housing secretary Steve Reed, also explores optional binding buyer-seller contracts to halve fall-throughs. Government offered no plan to stop sellers passing costs into prices. Measures must navigate differing regimes: England/Wales lack mandatory surveys; Scotland requires a home report and faster binding offers.

articles.title: Cut your energy bills by a third? No, these ‘energy-saving plugs’ will cause nothing but hassle
articles.trailText: The plastic ‘eco-plugs sold via social media or cold calls either never arrive or have no benefits when they do. And they can be dangerous
articles.summary: UK consumers are being targeted with energy-saving plugs, eco-plus boxes and voltage regulators sold via social media or cold calls, promising 30%+ bill cuts.
